<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/05/washington-redskins-seriously-considering-name-change?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Name Games
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Redskins owner Dan Snyder " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNjIxL3JlZHNraW5zX293bmVyX2Rhbl9zbnlkZXIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Patrick McDermott/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The NFL’s Washington Redskins are once again facing intense public scrutiny for their name, which is considered a racial slur in dictionary entries. But this time it looks like change may be on the horizon—longtime owner Dan Snyder <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/washingtons-nfl-team-to-undertake-thorough-review-of-redskins-name-11593792083?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released a statement</a> on Friday saying the team would be conducting a “thorough review” of the name.    </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What’s in a name?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Sports teams, mostly in the college ranks, have been <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/redskins-indians-and-the-long-push-to-drop-native-american-mascots-11593961353?mod=hp_lead_pos10&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">moving away</a> from stereotypical Native American names and imagery for decades.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In the 1970s, Stanford, Dartmouth, and Syracuse all swapped out their nicknames while professional teams, like the Cleveland Indians and Washington Redskins, have kept theirs. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But 2020 is a different story. As protests over racial injustice dominate the national conversation, big brands are comfortable using their dollars to initiate change.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>FedEx, which paid $205 million for the naming rights to Washington's stadium in 1999, </span><span><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/07/02/fedex-redskins-name-change/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made it clear</a></span><span> last week that it wants the team to change its name. And on Thursday, Nike appeared to pull all Redskins gear from its online store.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Those moves came after 87 investors and shareholders representing $620 billion in assets </span><span><a href="https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/investors-ask-nike-fedex-and-pepsico-to-end-relationships-with-the-washington-redskins/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called on</a></span><span> FedEx, Nike, and PepsiCo to cut ties to the team unless Snyder pursued a name change.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Which bring us to an important lesson</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Unless you're Babe Ruth and it's the fifth inning of Game 3 of the 1932 World Series, you might not want to guarantee anything.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Dan Snyder in 2013:</strong></span><span> "We'll never change the name...It's that simple. NEVER—you can use caps."</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Washington Redskins in 2020:</strong></span><span> “The team will undergo a thorough review of the team’s name.” </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Washington, which Forbes ranked as the seventh-most valuable NFL franchise in 2019, could set off a chain reaction if it commits to changing its name.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The MLB’s Cleveland Indians also </span><span><a href="https://thehill.com/homenews/news/505837-cleveland-indians-to-consider-name-change?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">released a statement</a></span><span> Friday saying they were considering a name change. That announcement comes after the team completely phased out its heavily criticized "Chief Wahoo" logo by 2019.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>this thing is happening. Washington is expected to <a href="https://www.axios.com/redskins-mascot-name-change-cfe194ab-b207-40bf-ae30-b883adf1c950.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">change its name</a> before kickoff in September, Axios reports. So here's our question for Brew readers: What should the new name be? <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/eIqZLYWn?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Share your answer here</a>. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENERGY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/05/buffett-makes-first-major-pandemic-purchase?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When Buffett Opens His Checkbook...
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">He makes it in the Brew. That’s the rules. After generating a whole lotta headlines for doing a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/04/business/dealbook/warren-buffett-coronavirus-cash.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">whole lotta nothing</a>, yesterday the legendary investor's company, Berkshire Hathaway, said it's <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/07/05/berkshire-hathaway-dominion-energy-gas-lines/5380788002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">acquiring natural gas assets</a> of Virginia-based Dominion Energy. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The deal, which is worth almost $10 billion including debt, is Buffett’s biggest addition by enterprise value to the Berkshire portfolio since 2016. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What’s Buffett getting? </strong>A little more gassy. Right now subsidiary Berkshire Hathaway Energy carries 8% of interstate natural gas transmission in the U.S. After the Dominion deal, that will <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/05/warren-buffetts-berkshire-buys-dominion-energy-natural-gas-assets-in-10-billion-deal.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jump to 18%</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What’s Dominion getting?</strong> A cleaner conscience. “We offer an industry-leading clean-energy profile,” said CEO Thomas Farrell in a statement, which he hopes just got industry-leadier after selling its natural gas assets. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In a separate announcement yesterday, Dominion said it was scrapping the $8 billion Atlantic Coast Pipeline project with Duke Energy due to mounting costs and regulatory hurdles. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Berkshire Hathaway has been sitting on an enormous pile of cash that just reached $137 billion. Perhaps the recent economic downturn has Buffett ready to wheel and deal. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD AND BEV
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/05/england-reopens-pubs-july-4?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
England Keeps Calm and Drinks On
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Cleaning up at a bar" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNjE5L2NsZWFuaW5nX3VwX2F0X2FfYmFyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Hollie Adams/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You might think reopening bars after more than three months and urging folks to not go bananas is a bit unrealistic, but England tried it anyway. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Dubbed “Super Saturday,” the government <a href="https://news.yahoo.com/fears-super-saturday-pubs-reopen-england-041745143.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lifted restrictions</a> on bars (and several other businesses) for the first time since late March. It’s a long-awaited moment for England’s 37,500 pubs, which furloughed 90% of their workers through a government relief program, the country’s Beer and Pub Association calculated.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, considering we are in a global pandemic, this will be a <a href="https://apnews.com/dc4775efdbeaa189ebd919012ad35565?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">different bar experience</a>:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>People won’t be able to congregate at the actual “bar,” so table service will be the norm.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>You’ll have to register with your info upon entering in case you need to be contacted later about a virus outbreak. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Background music will be quieter so that patrons don’t have to shout to talk to one another (please make this one permanent.)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>This is interesting: The wearing of face masks—by staff or by patrons—is optional. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>“Let’s not blow this,” said Prime Minister Boris Johnson.</p>

SPONSORED BY MASTERWORKS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

You Don’t Have to Take Big Risks to Make Big Returns
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It doesn’t take a degree in finance to know that the key to improving portfolio performance is diversification. Which is why when we learned that art has outperformed the S&P by over 180% since 2000 with little of the downside risk—people were bound to take notice.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Really, none of this should surprise us. The ultra-wealthy have collected art for centuries—but what about the rest of us?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, we have good news to report: <a href="https://www.masterworks.io/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_campaign=newsletter_7-6-20&utm_term=Morning%20Brew%20Subscribers&utm_content=newsletter" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Masterworks</a> is an exclusive, members-only platform that lets <em>anyone</em> (yes, you) buy and trade shares of multimillion-dollar paintings by artists like Banksy, Warhol, Basquiat, and more.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The only catch? There’s currently a backlog of over 25,000 of people applying for membership, but readers of the Brew can bypass the waitlist and skip to the front of the line by <a href="https://www.masterworks.io/?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_campaign=newsletter_7-6-20&utm_term=Morning%20Brew%20Subscribers&utm_content=newsletter" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">signing up today</a>.*</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENVIRONMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/05/ewaste-increased-21-five-years-un-report-finds?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Retired Gadgets Don’t Just Play Golf
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you didn't already have enough problems to worry about, let’s throw another on your plate: e-waste. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">E-waste, defined as discarded electronic gadgets like TVs, phones, and toasters, is a major and growing environmental problem, according to a new <a href="http://v?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">UN report</a>. The amount of e-waste has increased 21% over the last five years, reaching 54 million tonnes in 2019. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>If you’re craving an odd factoid, that’s the same amount of weight as </span><span><a href="https://www.zdnet.com/article/un-reports-global-e-waste-production-soared-beyond-53-million-tonnes-in-2019/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">350 cruise ships</a></span><span> the size of the Queen Mary 2.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Electronic gadgets fuel economic growth across the world, but as anyone with a $5 iPhone charger can attest, they have a short lifespan. 17% of e-waste was recycled in 2019, writes the UN, which means the rest of it was <a href="https://globalewaste.org/news/surge-global-waste/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">mostly dumped or burned</a>. That’s bad news, considering these devices contain hazardous materials, such as mercury. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But there’s opportunity. </strong>Electronics are also made of valuable materials that can be recovered and reused in a “circular economy.” The report estimates the value of raw materials in e-waste last year at $57 billion.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FROM THE CREW
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Start Talking
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>On Mondays, we'll present some of the thorniest business topics of the day, give you a jumping-off point with balanced resources, and encourage you to debate it with friends, family, and coworkers. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week’s topic:</strong> Reparations. In the last decade, racial reparations have gone from nonstarter to a point of debate in the <a href="https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/3/11/18246741/reparations-democrats-2020-inequality-warren-harris-castro?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Democratic presidential primary</a>. And you can bet you'll keep hearing about them, so here's your chance to learn more:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The 2014 article that started a national conversation: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s “The Case for Reparations” (The Atlantic—</span><span><a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/06/the-case-for-reparations/361631/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">print</a></span><span>, </span><span><a href="https://soundcloud.com/user-154380542/the-case-for-reparations-the-atlantic-ta-nehisi-coates?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">audio</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Why the argument for reparations feels different today (</span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/06/24/magazine/reparations-slavery.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NYT</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The economics of reparations (</span><span><a href="https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2020/06/20/the-economics-of-reparations?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Economist</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A brief history of reparations in the U.S. (</span><span><a href="https://www.brookings.edu/policy2020/bigideas/why-we-need-reparations-for-black-americans/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Brookings</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Why some critics believe they are logistically impossible (</span><span><a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2014/06/the-impossibility-of-reparations/372041/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Atlantic</a></span><span>)</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">

target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epleasantly surprised\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e by the economic recovery so far, citing consumer spending and new housing construction. He said that the extra $600 unemployment benefit provided by the first major relief package won’t be included in the next round of stimulus.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCOVID-19 update: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTexas and Florida each posted a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/04/florida-reports-more-than-11000-new-coronavirus-cases-another-daily-record.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erecord number\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of new coronavirus cases on Saturday. Houston’s mayor is \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/houston-mayor-hospitals-coronavirus-17dfcb0e-838b-44d0-b718-0a72c9e2d595.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003every concerned\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e about hospital capacity, while Florida represents about 20% of all new cases in the U.S.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nSPORTS\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nName Games\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Redskins owner Dan Snyder \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNjIxL3JlZHNraW5zX293bmVyX2Rhbl9zbnlkZXIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003ePatrick McDermott/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe NFL’s Washington Redskins are once again facing intense public scrutiny for their name, which is considered a racial slur in dictionary entries. But this time it looks like change may be on the horizon—longtime owner Dan Snyder \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/washingtons-nfl-team-to-undertake-thorough-review-of-redskins-name-11593792083?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased a statement\u003c/a\u003e on Friday saying the team would be conducting a “thorough review” of the name.    \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat’s in a name?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSports teams, mostly in the college ranks, have been \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/redskins-indians-and-the-long-push-to-drop-native-american-mascots-11593961353?mod=hp_lead_pos10\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emoving away\u003c/a\u003e from stereotypical Native American names and imagery for decades.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn the 1970s, Stanford, Dartmouth, and Syracuse all swapped out their nicknames while professional teams, like the Cleveland Indians and Washington Redskins, have kept theirs. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut 2020 is a different story. As protests over racial injustice dominate the national conversation, big brands are comfortable using their dollars to initiate change.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eFedEx, which paid $205 million for the naming rights to Washington's stadium in 1999, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/07/02/fedex-redskins-name-change/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade it clear\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e last week that it wants the team to change its name. And on Thursday, Nike appeared to pull all Redskins gear from its online store.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThose moves came after 87 investors and shareholders representing $620 billion in assets \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/investors-ask-nike-fedex-and-pepsico-to-end-relationships-with-the-washington-redskins/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled on\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e FedEx, Nike, and PepsiCo to cut ties to the team unless Snyder pursued a name change.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhich bring us to an important lesson\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUnless you're Babe Ruth and it's the fifth inning of Game 3 of the 1932 World Series, you might not want to guarantee anything.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDan Snyder in 2013:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e \"We'll never change the name...It's that simple. NEVER—you can use caps.\"\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWashington Redskins in 2020:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e “The team will undergo a thorough review of the team’s name.” \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWashington, which Forbes ranked as the seventh-most valuable NFL franchise in 2019, could set off a chain reaction if it commits to changing its name.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe MLB’s Cleveland Indians also \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://thehill.com/homenews/news/505837-cleveland-indians-to-consider-name-change?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereleased a statement\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Friday saying they were considering a name change. That announcement comes after the team completely phased out its heavily criticized \"Chief Wahoo\" logo by 2019.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethis thing is happening. Washington is expected to \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/redskins-mascot-name-change-cfe194ab-b207-40bf-ae30-b883adf1c950.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003echange its name\u003c/a\u003e before kickoff in September, Axios reports. So here's our question for Brew readers: What should the new name be? \u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/eIqZLYWn?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eShare your answer here\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHe makes it in the Brew. That’s the rules. After generating a whole lotta headlines for doing a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/04/business/dealbook/warren-buffett-coronavirus-cash.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewhole lotta nothing\u003c/a\u003e, yesterday the legendary investor's company, Berkshire Hathaway, said it's \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/07/05/berkshire-hathaway-dominion-energy-gas-lines/5380788002/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eacquiring natural gas assets\u003c/a\u003e of Virginia-based Dominion Energy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe deal, which is worth almost $10 billion including debt, is Buffett’s biggest addition by enterprise value to the Berkshire portfolio since 2016. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat’s Buffett getting? \u003c/strong\u003eA little more gassy. Right now subsidiary Berkshire Hathaway Energy carries 8% of interstate natural gas transmission in the U.S. After the Dominion deal, that will \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/05/warren-buffetts-berkshire-buys-dominion-energy-natural-gas-assets-in-10-billion-deal.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejump to 18%\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat’s Dominion getting?\u003c/strong\u003e A cleaner conscience. “We offer an industry-leading clean-energy profile,” said CEO Thomas Farrell in a statement, which he hopes just got industry-leadier after selling its natural gas assets. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn a separate announcement yesterday, Dominion said it was scrapping the $8 billion Atlantic Coast Pipeline project with Duke Energy due to mounting costs and regulatory hurdles. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e Berkshire Hathaway has been sitting on an enormous pile of cash that just reached $137 billion. Perhaps the recent economic downturn has Buffett ready to wheel and deal. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" calculated.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, considering we are in a global pandemic, this will be a \u003ca The amount of e-waste has increased 21% over the last five years, reaching 54 million tonnes in 2019. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIf you’re craving an odd factoid, that’s the same amount of weight as \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.zdnet.com/article/un-reports-global-e-waste-production-soared-beyond-53-million-tonnes-in-2019/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e350 cruise ships\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the size of the Queen Mary 2.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eElectronic gadgets fuel economic growth across the world, but as anyone with a $5 iPhone charger can attest, they have a short lifespan. 17% of e-waste was recycled in 2019, writes the UN, which means the rest of it was \u003ca href=\"https://globalewaste.org/news/surge-global-waste/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emostly dumped or burned\u003c/a\u003e. That’s bad news, considering these devices contain hazardous materials, such as mercury. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut there’s opportunity. \u003c/strong\u003eElectronics are also made of valuable materials that can be recovered and reused in a “circular economy.” The report estimates the
